docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate faces a third procedural vote this afternoon on its version of major health care overhaul, followed by a final vote Thursday at 8 a.m.

headline.main: Early Word: Senate Moves at Its Own Pace

docs.abstract: Senators take their second to last vote on the health care bill this afternoon as President Obama publicly defends his legislative record in his first year of office.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate voted 60 to 39 early Tuesday on three steps leading up to a final vote on sweeping health care legislation later this week.

headline.main: Parties Stay United as Health Bill Clears Steps in Senate
headline.print_headline: Senate Lays Groundwork for a Final Health Care Vote

docs.snippet: The Senate voted 60 to 39 early Tuesday on three steps leading up to a final vote on sweeping health care legislation later this week.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite the increasing confidence of Senate Democrats that they will pass health care legislation this week, Americans are still unhappy with Congressional efforts at an overhaul, according to two new polls. A Quinnipiac University poll released Tuesday found that 53 percent of the public disapproved of the effort and 36 percent supported it. The poll was taken last week, just as Senate Democrats were securing the votes necessary for passage.
docs.abstract: Quinnipiac University releases new poll showing that, despite increasing confidence of Senate Democrats, 53 percent of Americans polled disapprove of health care reform legislation and 36 percent support it; CNN poll finds that only 56 percent of respondents oppose Senate health care bill, compared with 61 percent who opposed it earlier in month (S)
docs.snippet: Despite the increasing confidence of Senate Democrats that they will pass health care legislation this week, Americans are still unhappy with Congressional efforts at an overhaul, according to two new polls.     A Quinnipiac University poll released...

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Parker Griffith of Alabama, who had compiled one of the more conservative voting records among House Democrats since being elected in 2008, said on Tuesday that he was becoming a Republican. Mr. Griffith, 67, below, announced the move while at home in his conservative northern Alabama district, the Fifth, saying he felt compelled to stand up to ''policies that burden our children with debt and threaten our economy.''
docs.abstract: Rep Parker Griffith (Ala), one of more conservative House Democrats, switches to Republican Party; Parker, who is oncologist, takes particular aim at Democrats' efforts to overhaul health care system; photo (S)
